Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER: Protecting Privacy in Untrusted Environments
----------------------------------------------------
PI: Vitaly Shmatikov (The University of Texas at Austin)

Information about individuals and organizations is increasingly collected
in massive databases, sent over public networks and shared across
organizational boundaries. This presents serious threats to privacy:
even if individual pieces of data are cryptographically protected,
sensitive information may still leak out due to mismatches between
privacy policies of different components.

This project aims to develop tools and techniques for protecting privacy
of sensitive data, focusing on three main research thrusts. The first
thrust is protection of public databases containing individual information
such as medical records, transactions, and preferences. This includes
design of provably secure methods for enforcing access policies directly
in published data, development of analysis tools for finding privacy
vulnerabilities, and evaluation on real-world data. The second thrust
is design and implementation of formal methods for checking privacy
policy compliance in order to ensure that data processing applications
do not violate the stated privacy policies of the enteprise. The third
thrust is development of new methods for analyzing privacy-preserving
communication networks.

Protecting data privacy is important not only for individuals, but
also for businesses and organizations that deal with individual data.
New technologies developed as part of this project will help detect
potential privacy violations and enforce privacy policies. They will
enable applications dealing with sensitive personal and organizational
data to be executed in open computing environments and support many
socially important tasks such as multi-institution medical trials that
do not violate patients' privacy and collaborative analysis of Internet
security threats.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on some of the most challenging problems faced by today's society: how to use people's sensitive personal data to enable myriad online and offline services that cannot function without it, yet do this without violating individuals' privacy; how to build computing systems that operate on sensitive data, yet do not leak it or use it improperly; how to use sensitive data in science and research, yet ensure that no harm can come to the individuals from whom the data was collected.

The first research goal pursued by this project was to understand privacy risks to sensitive individual data, such as social relationships, transactions, preferences, online and offline behavior, even biomedical and genetic records.  We demonstrated that many existing methods for "de-anonymizing" the data do not provide robust protection and can be defeated given the abundance of information about individuals in today's society.  This research influenced not only how data protection technologies are engineered today, but also laws, policies, and best practices world-wide.

 The second goal was to design, implement, and evaluate privacy-preserving computing systems that provide strong data privacy guarantees.  In the course of this project, we developed many software prototypes for a wide variety of scenarios: large-scale data analysis, mobile and Web apps, machine learning, and censorship-resistant communications. Several of our prototypes have been released as open source and adopted by the community.  In particular, our techniques for protecting the users of mobile devices from malicious advertising have been deployed on millions of Android devices.

This project supported several young computer scientists who gained exposure to data privacy research at an early stage of their careers. Over the course of the project, they matured from fresh PhD students into accomplished researchers and are now running their own research groups at major universities.
